org.jtrim2.stream

Class FluentSeqGroupMapper<T,R>

  • java.lang.Object
    • org.jtrim2.stream.FluentSeqGroupMapper<T,R>
  • Type Parameters:
    T - the type of the elements of the input stream
    R - the type of the elements this mapper is producing

    public final class FluentSeqGroupMapper<T,R>
extends java.lang.Object
    Defines a convenient fluent style builder for mappers mapping zero or more sequences of elements. Instances of this class can be created through the {SeqGroupMapper#toFluent() toFluent()} method of SeqGroupMapper.

    Mutator like methods always return a new instance and do not change the original SeqGroupMapper instance.

    For simple factory methods for initial mapper implementations, see the factory methods in SeqGroupMapper.

    Thread safety

    Instances of this class are immutable, and are therefor safe to be used by multiple threads concurrently. This property does not extend to the wrapped SeqGroupMapper.

    Synchronization transparency

    Methods of this class are synchronization transparent, so they can be called in any context (e.g.: while holding a lock).
    See Also:
    SeqGroupMapper.toFluent(), FluentSeqMapper

    • Method Detail

      • apply

        public <T1,R1> FluentSeqGroupMapper<T1,R1> apply(java.util.function.Function<? super SeqGroupMapper<T,R>,? extends SeqGroupMapper<T1,R1>> configurer)
        Transforms the wrapped SeqGroupMapper using the given function and returns a fluent style builder for the transformation result. This method exists to allow fluent style continuation using custom transformations.

        For an instance of FluentSeqGroupMapper named builder, this method call is equivalent to configurer.apply(builder.unwrap()).toFluent().

        Type Parameters:
        T1 - the type of the elements mapped by the returned mapper
        R1 - the type of the elements the returned mapper maps element to
        Parameters:
        configurer - the transformation transforming the wrapped mapper. This argument cannot be null, and the transformation cannot return null.
        Returns:
        the wrapped SeqGroupMapper transformed using the given function as fluent style builder. This method never returns null.

      • inBackground

        public FluentSeqGroupMapper<T,R> inBackground(java.lang.String executorName,
                                              int consumerThreadCount,
                                              int queueSize)
        Returns a mapper resplitting the mapped sequences into consumerThreadCount number of sequences and maps each sequence on a new separate thread.

        The implementation puts the received elements into a blocking queue, and proceeds to receive further elements. Aside from the potential parallelization, the benefit is that the producer and consumer runs in parallel, but if the producer is quicker, then it won't overload the memory and be blocked once the queue is full. That is, if the producer and consumer uses different resources, then you can achieve better resource utilization. If there is no or only insignificant variance between producing or processing element, then the queueSize argument can be set to zero to retain less elements concurrently.

        Parameters:
        executorName - the name given to the executor running the mapper tasks. This name will appear in the name of the executing threads. This argument cannot be null.
        consumerThreadCount - the number of threads mapping elements concurrently. This argument must be greater than or equal to zero.
        queueSize - the number of extra elements to store aside from what the mapper threads are processing. That is, the threads are effectively act as part of the queue. So, the total outstanding elements are consumerThreadCount + queueSize. This argument must be greater than or equal to zero. Setting this argument to zero is often appropriate, but can be set to a higher value to reduce the down time due to variance in producing and processing times.
        Returns:
        a mapper resplitting the mapped sequences into consumerThreadCount number of sequences and map each sequence on a new separate thread. This method never returns null.

      • inBackground

        public FluentSeqGroupMapper<T,R> inBackground(TaskExecutor executor,
                                              int consumerThreadCount,
                                              int queueSize)
        Returns a mapper resplitting the mapped sequences into consumerThreadCount number of sequences and maps each sequence in a new separate task of the given executor.

        The implementation puts the received elements into a blocking queue, and proceeds to receive further elements. Aside from the potential parallelization, the benefit is that the producer and consumer runs in parallel, but if the producer is quicker, then it won't overload the memory and be blocked once the queue is full. That is, if the producer and consumer uses different resources, then you can achieve better resource utilization. If there is no or only insignificant variance between producing or processing element, then the queueSize argument can be set to zero to retain less elements concurrently.

        Note that it is normally expected that the executor can run consumerThreadCount tasks in parallel (which will run for the whole duration of the whole processing uninterrupted), when submitted from the context where the jobs would be running otherwise. If that is not the case, then the implementation might assume that the jobs submitted to the executor will eventually start for the purpose of queue settings. However, dead-lock will only arise in case not even a single task submitted to the given executor can start running, and in that case dead-lock is a necessity.

        Parameters:
        executor - the executor running the mapper tasks. This argument cannot be null.
        consumerThreadCount - the number of threads mapping elements concurrently. This argument must be greater than or equal to zero.
        queueSize - the number of extra elements to store aside from what the mapper threads are processing. That is, the threads are effectively act as part of the queue. So, the total outstanding elements are consumerThreadCount + queueSize. This argument must be greater than or equal to zero. Setting this argument to zero is often appropriate, but can be set to a higher value to reduce the down time due to variance in producing and processing times.
        Returns:
        a mapper resplitting the mapped sequences into consumerThreadCount number of sequences and maps each sequence in a new separate task of the given executor. This method never returns null

      • toDrainingConsumer

        public FluentSeqGroupConsumer<T> toDrainingConsumer()
        Returns a FluentSeqGroupConsumer doing nothing with the output of this mapper, but the mapping action taking place in the returned consumer.
        Returns:
        a FluentSeqGroupConsumer doing nothing with the output of this mapper, but the mapping action taking place in the returned consumer. This method never returns null.

      • toConsumer

        public FluentSeqGroupConsumer<T> toConsumer(SeqGroupConsumer<? super R> seqGroupConsumer)
        Returns a FluentSeqGroupConsumer consuming the output of this mapper using the given consumer, where the mapping and element consumption taking place in the returned consumer.
        Parameters:
        seqGroupConsumer - the consumer consuming the output of this mapper (immediately after the mapping action on the same thread). This argument cannot be null.
        Returns:
        a FluentSeqGroupConsumer consuming the output of this mapper using the given consumer, where the mapping and element consumption taking place in the returned consumer. This method never returns null.

      • unwrap

        public SeqGroupMapper<T,R> unwrap()
        Returns the underlying SeqGroupMapper instance.
        Returns:
        the underlying SeqGroupMapper instance. This method never returns null.
